abstract.p: Let k, m, and r be three integers such that 2 ≤ k ≤ m ≤ r2≤k≤m≤r. Let G be a 2r2r-regular, 2m2m-edge-connected graph of odd order. We obtain some sufficient conditions for G − vG−v to contain a k-factor for all v ∈ V(G)v∈V(G).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: All graphs considered are multigraphs (with loops allowed) and finite. Let G be a graph with vertex set V(G)V(G) and edge set E(G)E(G). The number of vertices of a graph G is the order of G and is denoted by n. On the other hand, the number of edges of G is the size of G and is denoted by e. We denote the degree of vertex v in G by dG(v)dG(v). For two subsets S, T ⊆ V(G)S,T⊆V(G), let eG(S, T)eG(S,T) denote the number of edges of G joining S to T.

Let c(G)c(G) and co(G)co(G) denote the number of components and the number of odd components of G, respectively. Let k be a positive integer. A k-factor of a graph G is a spanning subgraph H of G such that dH(x) = kdH(x)=k for every x ∈ V(G)x∈V(G). Let D and S be disjoint subsets of V(G)V(G) and C be a component of G − (D ∪ S)G−(D∪S). C is a k-odd component of G − (D ∪ S)G−(D∪S) if k|C| + eG(S, V(C))k|C|+eG(S,V(C)) is odd.
Petersen obtained the following theorem, which is chronologically the first result on k-factors in regular graphs.

Clearly, H is 2r2r-regular (2r − 2)(2r−2)-edge-connected graph.
